Wednesday, April 29, 2020 at 6:30 p.m.
Held via Zoom Video Conference

PLEASE ALSO TAKE NOTICE THAT due to public health and safety concerns and pursuant to Executive Order 202.1 of the Governor of the State of New York, the public will NOT be permitted to attend this meeting in person or at the remote locations where the Board members will be. In the event that we are forced to close or delay the opening of the district or school you will receive a notification explaining the situation and providing specific guidance.
In general, emergency notifications are categorized into two main areas: delays and closures.

When a school is delayed this will impact both the start of school and associated transportation times. For example, if there is a 2-hour delay, school will start 2 hours later than normal. Additionally, for students that receive transportation services either to Pocantico or other schools, your pick-up time will be impacted by 2 hours. Students who would normally be picked up at 7:00am would now be picked up at 9:00am, etc.
When the Pocantico Hills Central School DISTRICT is closed, all activities, including all transportation services are cancelled.

If there is an event that is localized, such as a power outage on our campus, school will be closed, but transportation services to partner schools might still occur. When this happens, you will receive specific information regarding pick-up and drop-off times directly from Pocantico.

p.em: Partner schools will communicate directly with impacted families if they are delayed or closed.

strong.u: How Will You Receive The Message?

div.p: When an emergency occurs, you will be notified of the situation through a variety of communication channels. You will receive an automated call, as well as an e-mail, directly from the school, and the information will be posted on our website. Additionally, if you have opted to receive text messages and/or if you have the Pocantico Hills app, you will receive the notification through those channels as well. District specific weather-related closing information is also shared with News 12 Westchester, WABC-tv7, the Patch, WHUD 100.7. and Instagram: “superintendent.calkins” forgive the shameless promotionJ.

strong.u: When Will Closing Information Be Disseminated?

div.p: This information will be communicated to families in as timely a fashion as possible. Sometimes it may be feasible to notify you the night before the event takes place. Other times you will receive notifications in the morning. We will try to communicate this information to you between 5:30am and 6:00am.
Other Emergency Situations:

We will also utilize the aforementioned communication methodologies to communicate other emergency information to you. A good example of this would be if we were forced to close school and send our students home early.

img.alt: Cafeteria workers pack bags of food for school families who need it.

div.p: During the COVID-19 school closure, our cafeteria staff have been busy making sure that everyone who needs food assistance is receiving it. They deliver 500 meals per week.

img.alt: Cafeteria workers wrote "We miss you" with food.

div.p: While our district is happy to be helping families during this time, our cafeteria staff miss having everyone at school. They found a creative way to express how they feel!

img.alt: Tables were filled with canned and dry goods after families donated food to the school.

div.p: Pocantico staff are grateful for the generous food donations from the school community. The food will be used to assemble balanced care boxes for families in need.

img.alt: Children in the childcare program at Pocantico walk on a path behind the school.

div.p: While school is closed, Poco staff members are providing child care for families of medical personnel, first-responders and other essential employees.

img.alt: A mother and daughter dress in Poco blue during Spirit Week.

div.p: Many students and families participated in Poco Spirit Week April 6-10, including Blue Day.

img.alt: Two sisters wore "Poco Love" shirts during Poco Spirit Week.

div.p: Thank you to everyone who participated in Poco Spirit Week and submitted photos!

img.alt: Three siblings stand together on a path near school.

div.p: These siblings are having a lot of fun together in the special child care program while school is closed.

img.alt: A student holds up artwork she created for a sick hospital patient.

div.p: Children in our child care program have made pictures and drawings for people who are sick in the hospital.

img.alt: A student poses with artwork created for people who are hospitalized.

div.p: This is another student in the child care program displaying artwork for someone who is sick in a hospital.

img.alt: A boy holds up a Poco pillow that he made.

img.alt: A girl poses with an art project she created.

div.p: This is an art project one of our young students did at home.

img.alt: Student actors in Disney's "Moana JR." in a boat scene.

div.p: Before school closed, students were hard at work on Disney's "Moana JR.," a musical adaptation of the 2016 animated film.

img.alt: A scene with four girls in the school's production of Disney's "Moana JR."

div.p: The show, which has been postponed until further notice, is a coming-of-age story about Moana's quest to save her village and discover the truth about her heritage.

img.alt: An ensemble scene from Disney's "Moana JR."

div.p: Lin-Manuel Miranda, Opetaia Foa’i and Mark Mancina wrote the songs in the film, including “How Far I’ll Go,” “Shiny” and “You’re Welcome.”

img.alt: A scene from "Moana JR." with three students, including those playing Left Claw and Right Claw.

div.p: "Moana JR." celebrates the rich history of Oceania and is based on the beliefs and cultures of the people of the Pacific Islands.

img.alt: Facilities Director Donald Booth disinfects the school with an electrostatic sprayer.

div.p: Facilities Director Donald Booth disinfected with an electrostatic sprayer during a recent deep-cleaning of the school.

img.alt: Night supervisor Antonio Rivera cleans a desk.

div.p: Night supervisor Antonio Rivera wiped down a table during the cleaning, which took place on a Saturday.

img.alt: A member of the school's custodial staff helps clean a classroom.

div.p: A 12-person team cleaned and sprayed all surfaces in the school on March 8, from door handles and windows to gym lockers, furniture and garbage cans.

img.alt: A female student plays the Chinese harp during One World Evening.

div.p: The second annual One World Evening was a huge success. The event started with student performances of taekwondo, Indian and African dancing, and Chinese harp music.

img.alt: The school's Diversity Committee members pose for a group photo.

div.p: “This is a night to truly celebrate each other, our diversity, our cultural roots and just appreciate and enjoy and learn from each other and this most wonderful way,” said Principal Adam Brown, a Diversity Committee member.

img.alt: Students give a performance of Indian dancing at One World Evening.

div.p: One World Evening celebrates Pocantico's cultural diversity. In a school of about 320 students, families’ cultural roots span more than 100 countries.

img.alt: Parents pose with their two daughters during One World Evening.

div.p: So many families cooked and set up displays to share their culture. Some of the countries represented include Brazil, France, Colombia, India, Japan and Chile.

img.alt: A grandparent teaches a student origami during One World Evening.

div.p: In addition to sampling food from many cultures, many people tried arts and crafts such as origami, sand art and calligraphy.

img.alt: Girls perform African dance during One World Evening.

div.p: Many thanks to everyone who participated in One World Evening!

img.alt: A teacher introduces a new therapy dog to first-graders.

div.p: Duke's first day of school! Teacher Mario Suarez started introducing Duke on Feb. 10. Duke is the school's new therapeutic care dog. Children learned that he loves Cheerios.

img.alt: A teacher lets first-graders pet the school's new therapy dog.

div.p: Duke has been making the rounds of elementary school classrooms during his first week of school. Mr. Suarez will be introducing him to older students after February break.

img.alt: Teacher Mario Suarez and Duke, the school's new therapy dog.

div.p: Duke is very friendly and excited to meet everyone at Poco. Please remember not to pet him when he's wearing his red, "Do not pet" bandanna.

h2.span: Core Values: Kindness, Respect and Perseverance

div.p: As part of our successful transition back to school, our 8th grade students were charged with creating a school-wide character pledge that reflects our core values—kindness, respect and perseverance. Their successful work was chronicled throughout the week and captured on video Pocantico Character. Our Pocantico Character Pledge is recited each morning following the Pledge of Allegiance as a school community. Again, a special thank you to the class of 2019 and Mr. Murray, Mrs. Carruth and Mrs. Hongell, who facilitated this important work with our students.
As a student of character at Pocantico Hills …

p.em: I pledge to not give up when obstacles are in the way. I will persevere.
I will listen to others and use careful words. I will be respectful.
I will smile and greet people in the hallways. I will be kind.
